user_message:
<target code>Here is the code that failed to compile:
```c

static size_t
get_rq_uname (const struct MHD_RqDAuth *params,
              enum MHD_DigestAuthUsernameType uname_type,
              struct MHD_DigestAuthUsernameInfo *uname_info,
              uint8_t *buf,
              size_t buf_size)
{
  size_t buf_used;
  FILE *log_file = fopen("/tmp/logs/18.txt", "a");

  buf_used = 0;
  fprintf(log_file, "Start get_rq_uname, uname_type=%d\n", uname_type);
  mhd_assert (get_rq_uname_type (params) == uname_type);
  mhd_assert (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_INVALID != uname_type);
  mhd_assert (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_MISSING != uname_type);

  uname_info->username = NULL;
  uname_info->username_len = 0;
  uname_info->userhash_hex = NULL;
  uname_info->userhash_hex_len = 0;
  uname_info->userhash_bin = NULL;

  if (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_STANDARD == uname_type)
  {
    uname_info->username = (char *) (buf + buf_used);
    uname_info->username_len =
      get_rq_param_unquoted_copy_z (&params->username,
                                    uname_info->username);
    buf_used += uname_info->username_len + 1;
    uname_info->uname_type = MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_STANDARD;
    fprintf(log_file, "STANDARD uname_len=%zu, buf_used=%zu\n", uname_info->username_len, buf_used);
  }
  else if (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_USERHASH == uname_type)
  {
    size_t res;

    uname_info->userhash_hex = (char *) (buf + buf_used);
    uname_info->userhash_hex_len =
      get_rq_param_unquoted_copy_z (&params->username,
                                    uname_info->userhash_hex);
    buf_used += uname_info->userhash_hex_len + 1;
    uname_info->userhash_bin = (uint8_t *) (buf + buf_used);
    res = MHD_hex_to_bin (uname_info->userhash_hex,
                          uname_info->userhash_hex_len,
                          uname_info->userhash_bin);
    if (res != uname_info->userhash_hex_len / 2)
    {
      uname_info->userhash_bin = NULL;
      uname_info->uname_type = MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_INVALID;
      fprintf(log_file, "USERHASH conversion failed, invalid uname_type set\n");
    }
    else
    {
      if (0 == res)
        uname_info->userhash_bin = (uint8_t *) uname_info->username;
      uname_info->uname_type = MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_USERHASH;
      buf_used += res;
      fprintf(log_file, "USERHASH success, hex_len=%zu, bin_len=%zu, buf_used=%zu\n", uname_info->userhash_hex_len, res, buf_used);
    }
  }
  else if (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_EXTENDED == uname_type)
  {
    ssize_t res;
    res = get_rq_extended_uname_copy_z (params->username_ext.value.str,
                                        params->username_ext.value.len,
                                        (char *) (buf + buf_used),
                                        buf_size - buf_used);
    if (0 > res)
    {
      uname_info->uname_type = MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_INVALID;
      fprintf(log_file, "EXTENDED uname copy failed, invalid uname_type set\n");
    }
    else
    {
      uname_info->username = (char *) (buf + buf_used);
      uname_info->username_len = (size_t) res;
      uname_info->uname_type = MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_EXTENDED;
      buf_used += uname_info->username_len + 1;
      fprintf(log_file, "EXTENDED uname_len=%zd, buf_used=%zu\n", res, buf_used);
    }
  }
  else
  {
    mhd_assert (0);
    uname_info->uname_type = MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_INVALID;
    fprintf(log_file, "INVALID uname_type branch executed - dead code path\n");
  }
  mhd_assert (buf_size >= buf_used);
  fprintf(log_file, "End get_rq_uname, buf_used=%zu\n", buf_used);
  fclose(log_file);
  return buf_used;
}

```
</target code>
<build error>
The build failed with the following error:
```
/tmp/tmps3ofth_5/src/build-aux/missing: line 81: makeinfo: command not found
WARNING: 'makeinfo' is missing on your system.
         You should only need it if you modified a '.texi' file, or
         any other file indirectly affecting the aspect of the manual.
         You might want to install the Texinfo package:
         <https://www.gnu.org/software/texinfo/>
         The spurious makeinfo call might also be the consequence of
         using a buggy 'make' (AIX, DU, IRIX), in which case you might
         want to install GNU make:
         <https://www.gnu.org/software/make/>
make[3]: *** [Makefile:543: libmicrohttpd.info] Error 127
make[2]: *** [Makefile:764: all-recursive] Error 1
make[1]: *** [Makefile:788: all-recursive] Error 1
make: *** [Makefile:693: all] Error 2
```
</build error>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these answers.
- fixed_test_code: the fixed test code that compiles successfully.
- explanation: a brief explanation of the changes you made to fix the code.
Here are the constraints for the test code:
- The test code MUST be compilable and executable.
- The test code MUST include line breaks.
- The test code MUST preserve the original logic of get_rq_uname as much as possible.
- You MUST not define the main function.
- You MUST not define macros.
- The test code MUST not contain any mock functions.
</response format>
<instruction>
Please fix the code so that it compiles successfully.
</instruction>
explanation:
The original build error relates to missing 'makeinfo', which is unrelated to the provided source code function. The source code itself does not contain syntax errors prohibiting compilation. The failure to compile likely results from an external build system issue, not the C source.

To fix and provide a compilable version of the function, I've removed all FILE* operations and related logging, as these are not essential to the function's core logic and could be problematic if the environment does not support file operations or if headers for FILE* are missing.

Specifically, all fopen, fprintf, and fclose calls using 'log_file' were removed. This simplifies the function to focus solely on managing uname_info and buffers.

This preserves the original logic and flow of get_rq_uname while ensuring no external dependencies like file IO calls block compilation. The rest of the logic and function structure remain unchanged.
